Date Class

　The functionality to create a Date object from a string and the functionality to create a string from an object are currently unimplemented, but otherwise it is mostly compatible with JavaScript's Date.

　The constructor syntax is as follows:

new Date();
new Date(<date string>);
new Date(<year>, <month(0~)=0>, <day=1>, <hour=0>, <minute=0>, <second=0>);
　The first syntax requires no arguments. In this case, it holds the current date and time at the moment the constructor is executed.
　The second syntax specifies a date string. The date string must be in ANSI C asctime() format, defined in RFC1123, defined in RFC1036, or in the "year/month/day hour:minute:second" format. Recognition of the date string is automatic and accommodates some variation in format, but it may not be recognized if it deviates too much from the expected formats.
　The third syntax specifies the year, month, day, hour, minute, and second.

　Implemented methods (JavaScript compatible):
setYear/getYear (Set/get 4-digit calendar year in local time)
setMonth/getMonth (Set/get month in local time)
setDate/getDate (Set/get day of the month in local time)
setHours/getHours (Set/get hours in local time)
setMinutes/getMinutes (Set/get minutes in local time)
setSeconds/getSeconds (Set/get seconds in local time)
setTime/getTime (Set/get elapsed milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 0:00)
getDay (Get day of the week)
parse (Interpret date string)
